etymologies: Middle English: from Old French reserver, from Latin reservare ‘keep back’, from re- ‘back’ + servare ‘to keep’

definitions: refrain from using or disposing of (something); retain for future use

examples.text: roll out half the dough and reserve the other half

shortDefinitions: refrain from using or disposing of

definitions: arrange for (a room, seat, ticket, etc.) to be kept for the use of a particular person and not given to anyone else

examples.text: a place was reserved for her in the front row

shortDefinitions: arrange for (room, seat, ticket, etc.) to be kept for use of particular person

definitions: retain or hold (an entitlement to something), especially by formal or legal stipulation

examples.text: the editor reserves the right to edit letters

shortDefinitions: retain or hold entitlement to something

definitions: refrain from delivering (a judgment or decision) immediately or without due consideration or evidence

examples.text: I'll reserve my views on his ability until he's played again

shortDefinitions: refrain from delivering judgment or decision immediately or without due consideration or evidence

definitions: use or engage in something only in or at (a particular circumstance or time)

examples.text: Japanese food has been presented as expensive and reserved for special occasions

shortDefinitions: use or engage in something only in or at

definitions: (in church use) retain (a portion of the consecrated elements) after mass for communion of the sick or as a focus for devotion.
shortDefinitions: retain portion of consecrated elements after mass

definitions: a supply of a commodity not needed for immediate use but available if required

examples.text: Australia has major coal, gas, and uranium reserves

shortDefinitions: supply of commodity not needed for immediate use but available if required

definitions: funds kept available by a bank, company, or government
shortDefinitions: funds kept available by bank or government

definitions: a part of a company's profits added to capital rather than paid as a dividend

examples.text: the bank built up a cash reserve of $2bn to meet any run on the bank once the loss was revealed

shortDefinitions: part of company's profits added to capital rather than paid as dividend

definitions: a force or body of troops kept back from action to reinforce or protect others, or additional to the regular forces and available in an emergency

examples.text: the men were stationed as a central reserve ready to be transported wherever necessary

shortDefinitions: body of troops withheld from action to reinforce or protect others

definitions: a member of the military reserve

examples.text: the army began calling up reserves for combat training

definitions: an extra player who is a possible substitute in a team

examples.text: he was reserve hooker for the World Cup team

shortDefinitions: extra player in team, serving as possible substitute

examples.text: playing in the first team has been a big step up after the reserves

definitions: a place set aside for special use.
shortDefinitions: place set aside for special use

definitions: a reservation for an indigenous people

examples.text: a reserve was allocated to the tribe on Bear Island
part of the marshes has been managed to create a splendid reserve full of birds

definitions: a lack of warmth or openness in manner or expression

examples.text: she smiled and some of her natural reserve melted

shortDefinitions: lack of warmth or openness in manner or expression

definitions: qualification or doubt attached to some statement or claim
shortDefinitions: feeling of doubt qualifying acceptance of person or plan

definitions: (in the decoration of ceramics or textiles) an area that still has the original color of the material or the color of the background.
shortDefinitions: area in which original material or background colour remains visible
